citations.narrative:
The indoor portion of a young red fox's enclosures has metal siding that is rusted and has sharp edges. Additionally the
facility uses heated water bowls, which is unplugged, the young red fox has pulled the cord into the enclosure and is
chewing on the plug-in end of the cord. The rusted, sharp siding may cause injury and the electric cord may be an
ingestion hazard to the fox. The indoor and outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained
in good repair to protect the animals from injury and to contain the animals.

The only water receptacle for three white-tailed deer has a layer of thin, green organic film covering the majority of the
inside of the receptacle. Buildup of organic material in water does not provide the animals potable water and may lead to
health problems like dehydration or disease. The facility must provide potable water and ensure the water receptacle is
kept clean and sanitary.
To be corrected by: 15-May-2024

There were sharp points and edges found in two raptor primary enclosures. The barred owl enclosure had two screws
protruding from a wooden perch. The peregrine falcon enclosure had one nail sticking out from a wooden perch. An
approximate 3 inch section of metal siding along the bottom of the peregrine falcon enclosure has rusted creating a sharp
edge. This edge can be seen on the inside and outside of the enclosure. Sharp edges and points may cause injury to the
birds. Primary enclosures must be designed and constructed of suitable materials so that they are structurally sound. The
primary enclosures must be kept in good repair. Primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that they
have no sharp points or edges that could injure the birds.
To be corrected by: 17-May-2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
3.125(a)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
The indoor portion of a young red fox's enclosures has metal siding that is rusted and has sharp edges. Additionally the 
facility uses heated water bowls, which is unplugged, the young red fox has pulled the cord into the enclosure and is 
chewing on the plug-in end of the cord. The rusted, sharp siding may cause injury and the electric cord may be an 
ingestion hazard to the fox. The indoor and outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained 
in good repair to protect the animals from injury and to contain the animals. 
3.130 
   
Watering. 
The only water receptacle for three white-tailed deer has a layer of thin, green organic film covering the majority of the 
inside of the receptacle. Buildup of organic material in water does not provide the animals potable water and may lead to 
health problems like dehydration or disease. The facility must provide potable water and ensure the water receptacle is 
kept clean and sanitary. 
To be corrected by: 15-May-2024 
3.153(a)(1)(i) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
There were sharp points and edges found in two raptor primary enclosures. The barred owl enclosure had two screws 
protruding from a wooden perch. The peregrine falcon enclosure had one nail sticking out from a wooden perch. An 
approximate 3 inch section of metal siding along the bottom of the peregrine falcon enclosure has rusted creating a sharp 
edge. This edge can be seen on the inside and outside of the enclosure. Sharp edges and points may cause injury to the 
birds. Primary enclosures must be designed and constructed of suitable materials so that they are structurally sound. The 
primary enclosures must be kept in good repair. Primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that they 
have no sharp points or edges that could injure the birds. 
To be corrected by: 17-May-2024 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.

n

species.common: RED FOX (INCLUDES SILVER FOX & CROSS FOX)
